title: Accessing Concordance Statistics
text: explore results, first need install load local instance demcrit R package:
code: # If you do not have the devtools package, # install it by uncommenting the following line: #install.packages(devtools) devtools::install_github("josefmana/demcrit")

title: Accessing Concordance Statistics
text: installed, concordance statistics can loaded. following code chunk loads demcrit package (subsequent examples assume package already loaded) reads concordance data object concords: can find detailed description dataset documentation: concords object tibble, meaning can easily manipulated using packages tidyverse ecosystem.
code: library(demcrit) data("concords") help("concords")

title: Accessing Concordance Statistics
text: example, following code filters data retain pairwise comparisons algorithm "Lvl.II (1)" served reference: nuanced data operations, can also load rates dataset, contains algorithm specifications estimated rates probable PDD sample: Using datasets, possible, instance, retain comparisons "Lvl.II (1)" served reference predictor used operationalisation IADL deficit. resulting data can sorted, example, predictor‚Äôs specificity (highest lowest):
code: library(tidyverse) # load the package  # Extract the subdata: lvlII1_reference <- concords |>   filter(reference == "Lvl.II (1)") data("rates") help("rates") # Extract operationalisation of IADL deficit # used by the "Lvl.II (1)" algorithm: IADL_oper <- subset(rates, type == "Lvl.II (1)")$IADL  # Find algorithms using the same operationalisation: algos_of_interest <- subset(rates, IADL == IADL_oper)$type  # Keep only pairs of interest: lvlII1_reference_2 <- concords |>   filter(reference == "Lvl.II (1)") |>   filter(predictor %in% algos_of_interest) |>   arrange(desc(Specificity))

title: Accessing Concordance Statistics
text: Finally, can export data CSV Excel format use software. following examples use readr writexl packages, though preferred method can used:
code: # Export to CSV: readr::write_csv(concords, "demcrit_concordance_stats.csv")  # Export to Excel (single sheet): writexl::write_xlsx(concords, "demcrit_concordance_stats.xlsx")  # Export to Excel (two sheets: concordance statistics and algorithm details): writexl::write_xlsx(   list(concordance = concords, algorithms = rates),   path = "demcrit_concordance_stats_with_algos.xlsx" )  # Note: Adjust the second argument to whatever # "path/to/your/data" you find suitable.

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: question straightforward one address conceptually, conducted brief simulation experiment explore empirically. vignette presents R code results simulation study comparing algorithms‚Äô concordance PDD rate estimates simplified setting. scenario, differences algorithms operationalisations IADL deficit (FAQ > 7 vs.¬†FAQ item 9 < 1) global cognitive deficit (MMSE < 26 vs.¬†MoCA < 26), diagnostic criteria assumed satisfied. Crucially, within algorithms, vary correlation FAQ MMSE/MoCA data-generating process, allowing us compare estimates two conditions: one correlation (independent scenario) one correlation size consistent observed data (correlated scenario, see Table¬†1). Table¬†1: Distribution moments (means standard deviations) Pearson‚Äôs correlations FAQ, MMSE MoCA measured observed data.

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: approximate situation examined study, simulate FAQ, MMSE MoCA data common multivariate. words, subject ii assumed following vector latent scores: Yi=[FAQiMMSEiMoCAi]‚àº‚Ñ≥ùí±ùí©3(ùõç,ùö∫)(1)  Y_i = \begin{bmatrix} FAQ_i \\ MMSE_i \\ MoCA_i \end{bmatrix} \sim \mathcal{MVN_3}(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})  \qquad(1) ùõç\boldsymbol\mu denotes vector means ùö∫\boldsymbol\Sigma variance‚Äìcovariance matrix. Across simulations, vector means fixed based observed data (see Table¬†1): ùõç=[4.0526.6924.07](2) \boldsymbol\mu = \begin{bmatrix} 4.05 \\ 26.69 \\ 24.07 \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(2) Two different specification variance-covariance matrix used. first, based observed data (Table¬†1), represents correlated scenario: ùö∫corr=[23.91‚àí2.28‚àí4.59‚àí2.284.934.87‚àí4.594.8724.07](3) \boldsymbol\Sigma_{corr} =   \begin{bmatrix} 23.91 & -2.28 & -4.59 \\                   -2.28 &  4.93 & 4.87  \\                   -4.59 &  4.87 & 24.07   \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(3) simulate independent scenario, covariance FAQ MMSE/MoCA set zero, yielding: ùö∫indep=[23.910004.934.8704.8724.07](4) \boldsymbol\Sigma_{indep} =   \begin{bmatrix} 23.91 &  0    & 0    \\                    0    &  4.93 & 4.87  \\                    0    &  4.87 & 24.07   \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(4) simulate data FAQ item 9, assumed ùõï\boldsymbol{\tau}-equivalence FAQ (.e., items share true score, cf. Trizano-Hermosilla Alvarado (2016)). applied probit link FAQ total score simulated patient obtain probability positive response item: pi=œï(zi)(5) p_i = \phi(z_i)  \qquad(5) œï(‚ãÖ)\phi(\cdot) standard normal cumulative distribution function ziz_i standardised FAQ score simulated patient ii. observed FAQ item 9 score subsequently drawn binomial distribution via: FAQ item 9i‚àº‚Ñ¨ùíæùìÉ‚Ñ¥ùìÇùíæùí∂ùìÅ(n=4,pi)(6) \text{FAQ item 9}_i \sim \mathcal{Binomial}(n = 4, p_i)  \qquad(6) simulated FAQ item 9 score exceeded corresponding simulated FAQ total score, set zero. Finally, simulated FAQ total, MMSE MoCA scores left-censored 0 right-censored 30 reflect real-world range respective scales.
code: # Simulation parameters: n <- 2000 # sample size high enough to get stable estimates k <- 2000 # enough iterations to see trends   # Moments of the multivariate normal distribution: mu <- c(FAQ = 4.05, MMSE = 26.69, MoCA = 24.07) # vector of means sigma <- c(FAQ = 4.89, MMSE = 2.22, MoCA = 3.48) # vector of standard deviations  # Correlation matrix from observed data: corrs <- matrix(   c(1, -0.21, -0.27,     -0.21, 1, 0.63,     -0.27, 0.63, 1),   nrow = 3,   dimnames = list(     c("FAQ", "MMSE", "MoCA"),     c("FAQ", "MMSE", "MoCA")   ) )  # Get variance-covariance matrix for the correlated case: sigma_corr <- cor2cov(corrs, sigma)  # Set FAQ/cognition covariances to zero for the independent case: sigma_indep <- sigma_corr sigma_indep["FAQ", ] <- c(sigma_indep["FAQ", "FAQ"], 0, 0) sigma_indep[, "FAQ"] <- c(sigma_indep["FAQ", "FAQ"], 0, 0)  # Set censoring values: cens <- matrix(   c(rep(0, 3), rep(30, 3)), nrow = 3,   dimnames = list(c("FAQ", "MMSE", "MoCA")) )  # Set criteria: crits <- data.frame(   row.names = c("A1", "A2", "A3", "A4"),   IADL = rep(c("FAQ", "FAQ9"), 2),   IADL_thres = rep(c(7, 1), 2),   cognition = c(rep("MMSE", 2), rep("MoCA", 2)),   cognition_thres = c(rep(26, 2), rep(26, 2)) )

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: approximate situation examined study, simulate FAQ, MMSE MoCA data common multivariate. words, subject ii assumed following vector latent scores: Yi=[FAQiMMSEiMoCAi]‚àº‚Ñ≥ùí±ùí©3(ùõç,ùö∫)(1)  Y_i = \begin{bmatrix} FAQ_i \\ MMSE_i \\ MoCA_i \end{bmatrix} \sim \mathcal{MVN_3}(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})  \qquad(1) ùõç\boldsymbol\mu denotes vector means ùö∫\boldsymbol\Sigma variance‚Äìcovariance matrix. Across simulations, vector means fixed based observed data (see Table¬†1): ùõç=[4.0526.6924.07](2) \boldsymbol\mu = \begin{bmatrix} 4.05 \\ 26.69 \\ 24.07 \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(2) Two different specification variance-covariance matrix used. first, based observed data (Table¬†1), represents correlated scenario: ùö∫corr=[23.91‚àí2.28‚àí4.59‚àí2.284.934.87‚àí4.594.8724.07](3) \boldsymbol\Sigma_{corr} =   \begin{bmatrix} 23.91 & -2.28 & -4.59 \\                   -2.28 &  4.93 & 4.87  \\                   -4.59 &  4.87 & 24.07   \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(3) simulate independent scenario, covariance FAQ MMSE/MoCA set zero, yielding: ùö∫indep=[23.910004.934.8704.8724.07](4) \boldsymbol\Sigma_{indep} =   \begin{bmatrix} 23.91 &  0    & 0    \\                    0    &  4.93 & 4.87  \\                    0    &  4.87 & 24.07   \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(4)

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: simulate data FAQ item 9, assumed ùõï\boldsymbol{\tau}-equivalence FAQ (.e., items share true score, cf. Trizano-Hermosilla Alvarado (2016)). applied probit link FAQ total score simulated patient obtain probability positive response item: pi=œï(zi)(5) p_i = \phi(z_i)  \qquad(5) œï(‚ãÖ)\phi(\cdot) standard normal cumulative distribution function ziz_i standardised FAQ score simulated patient ii. observed FAQ item 9 score subsequently drawn binomial distribution via: FAQ item 9i‚àº‚Ñ¨ùíæùìÉ‚Ñ¥ùìÇùíæùí∂ùìÅ(n=4,pi)(6) \text{FAQ item 9}_i \sim \mathcal{Binomial}(n = 4, p_i)  \qquad(6) simulated FAQ item 9 score exceeded corresponding simulated FAQ total score, set zero. Finally, simulated FAQ total, MMSE MoCA scores left-censored 0 right-censored 30 reflect real-world range respective scales.

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: generating data using process described , simulated patient classified suffering PDD () according following four algorithms: A1i=ùüô{FAQi>7‚àßMMSEi<26},A2i=ùüô{FAQ item 9i>1‚àßMMSEi<26},A3i=ùüô{FAQi>7‚àßMoCAi<26},A4i=ùüô{FAQ item 9i>1‚àßMoCAi<26}(7) \begin{aligned}   A1_i &= \mathbb{1}\{\text{FAQ}_i > 7 \ \wedge\ \text{MMSE}_i < 26\}, \\   A2_i &= \mathbb{1}\{\text{FAQ item 9}_i > 1 \ \wedge\ \text{MMSE}_i < 26\}, \\   A3_i &= \mathbb{1}\{\text{FAQ}_i > 7 \ \wedge\ \text{MoCA}_i < 26\}, \\   A4_i &= \mathbb{1}\{\text{FAQ item 9}_i > 1 \ \wedge\ \text{MoCA}_i < 26\} \end{aligned}  \qquad(7) ùüô{‚ãÖ}\mathbb{1}\{\cdot\} denotes indicator function. words, simulated cases fulfilling conditions parentheses classified PDD (PDD = 1); others classified non-PDD (PDD = 0). ensure reliable results, N = 2000 cases generated experiment. simulation based observed means, standard deviations correlations specified . independent variable experiment presence versus absence correlation FAQ cognitive scores. Accordingly, simulation conducted two conditions: Independent scenario using ùö∫indep\boldsymbol\Sigma_{indep} (Equation¬†4), Correlated scenario using ùö∫corr\boldsymbol\Sigma_{corr} (Equation¬†3). simulation parameters (.e., number participants, vector variable means, variances variables, covariance MMSE MoCA) held constant across conditions.

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: ensure reliable results, N = 2000 cases generated experiment. simulation based observed means, standard deviations correlations specified . independent variable experiment presence versus absence correlation FAQ cognitive scores. Accordingly, simulation conducted two conditions: Independent scenario using ùö∫indep\boldsymbol\Sigma_{indep} (Equation¬†4), Correlated scenario using ùö∫corr\boldsymbol\Sigma_{corr} (Equation¬†3). simulation parameters (.e., number participants, vector variable means, variances variables, covariance MMSE MoCA) held constant across conditions.

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: generated data, following statistical estimates computed within scenario (.e., independent correlated): PDD rate algorithm, accuracy pair algorithms, balanced accuracy pair algorithms, Cohen‚Äôs ùõã\boldsymbol\kappa pair algorithms. procedure repeated 2000 iterations. Subsequently, distributions PDD rates concordance measures compared (pairs ) algorithms across two scenarios. Independent samples t-tests used compute 95% confidence intervals differences scenarios within diagnostic algorithm.
code: # Function for comparing two algorithms within the same scenario: compare_algos <- function(dat, a1, a2) {   x <- dat[[a1]]   y <- dat[[a2]]   cm <- caret::confusionMatrix(factor(x), factor(y), positive = "1")   k <- psych::cohen.kappa(cbind(x, y))$kappa   data.frame(     Accuracy = cm$overall["Accuracy"],     BalAcc = cm$byClass["Balanced Accuracy"],     Kappa = k   ) }  # Function for results summary: summarise_results <- function(d0, d1, r = 1) {   # PDD rates:   rates <- map_dfr(paste0("A", 1:4), function(i) {     c(indep = mean(d0[[i]]),       corrs = mean(d1[[i]])       )   }) |>     mutate(diff = corrs - indep, rep  = r) |>     rownames_to_column("algo")   # Concordance:   conc <- expand.grid(     ref = paste0("A", 1:4),     pred = paste0("A", 1:4),     scenario = c("indep", "corrs")   )   for (i in c("Accuracy", "BalAcc", "Kappa")) {     conc[[i]] <- NA   }   for (i in seq_len(nrow(conc))) {     y <- as.character(conc[i, "ref"])     x <- as.character(conc[i, "pred"])     if (conc[i, "scenario"] == "indep") {       conc[i , c("Accuracy", "BalAcc", "Kappa")] <- compare_algos(d0, x, y)     } else if (conc[i, "scenario"] == "corrs") {       conc[i, c("Accuracy", "BalAcc", "Kappa")] <- compare_algos(d1, x, y)     }   }   conc$rep <- r   # Return the results:   list(rates = rates, concordance = as_tibble(conc)) }

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: expected values (denoted E(‚ãÖ)E(\cdot)) differences independent correlated scenarios PDD rates, accuracy, balanced accuracy Cohen‚Äôs Œ∫\kappa presented Table¬†2, Table¬†3, Table¬†4, Table¬†5, respectively. Across algorithms, correlated scenario generated higher PDD rates independent scenario, differences approximately 2-4% (Table¬†2). Table¬†2: Expectations PDD rates differences independent correlated scenarios based independent sample t-tests. effect data-generating scenario concordance indeces nuanced. accuracy, correlated scenario generally yielded slightly lower estimates independent one across algorithm pairs (Table¬†3). However, magnitude differences exceed 2%. Table¬†3: Expectations accuracy estimates differences independent correlated scenarios based independent sample t-tests. Results balanced accuracy heterogeneous (Table¬†4). algorithm pairs IADL global cognition criteria mismatched (e.g., A1 vs A4), balanced accuracy consistently higher correlated scenario, roughly 3%. mismatch concerned IADL criterion, direction difference balanced accuracy reversed depending algorithm used reference (e.g., A1 predicted A2, correlated scenario yielded lower balanced accuracy, whereas A2 predicted A1, yielded higher values). magnitude effect higher direction correlated scenario yielding higher estimates. Finally, mismatch involved global cognition criterion, correlated scenario led higher balanced accuracy estimates three four cases. maximum difference similar comparison types, reaching 3.2%. Table¬†4: Expectations balanced accuracy estimates differences independent correlated scenarios based independent sample t-tests. Lastly, Cohen‚Äôs Œ∫\kappa showed clearest consistent pattern results (Table¬†5). cases, correlated scenario yielded higher Œ∫\kappa values independent one, differences ranging 0.014 0.068. Table¬†5: Expectations Cohen‚Äôs Œ∫ estimates differences independent correlated scenarios based independent sample t-tests.
code: # Calculate all results: res <- lapply(seq_len(k), function(i) {   d0 <- simulate_pdd_data(n, FALSE, mu, sigma_indep, crits, cens) |> # independent scenario     mutate(PDD = as.numeric(PDD)) |>     pivot_wider(names_from = "type", values_from = "PDD")   d1 <- simulate_pdd_data(n, FALSE, mu, sigma_corr, crits, cens) |> # correlated scenario     mutate(PDD = as.numeric(PDD)) |>     pivot_wider(names_from = "type", values_from = "PDD")   summarise_results(d0, d1, i) })  # Extract PDD rates and concordance separately: res_rates <- map_dfr(seq_len(k), \(i) res[[i]]$rates) res_conc <- map_dfr(seq_len(k), \(i) res[[i]]$conc)  # Conduct t-tests for PDD rates: stats_rates <- res_rates |>   pivot_longer(c(indep, corrs), names_to = "scenario", values_to = "rate") |>   group_by(algo) |>   rstatix::t_test(rate ~ scenario, detailed = TRUE, var.equal = TRUE) |>   mutate(     Algorithm = glue::glue("A{algo}"),     Independent = estimate2,     Correlated = estimate1,     Difference = estimate,     Low = conf.low,     High = conf.high   ) |>   dplyr::select(Algorithm, Independent, Correlated, Difference, Low, High)  # Conduct t-tests for concordance metrics: stats_conc <- map_dfr(c("Accuracy", "BalAcc", "Kappa"), function(y) {   res_conc |>     filter(ref != pred) |>     mutate(Comparison = glue::glue("{ref}{pred}")) |>     group_by(Comparison) |>     rstatix::t_test(formula(glue::glue("{y} ~ scenario")), detailed = TRUE, var.equal = TRUE) |>     mutate(       Index = y,       Independent = estimate1,       Correlated = estimate2,       Difference = estimate,       Low = conf.low,       High = conf.high,       Type = case_when(         Comparison %in% c("A1A3", "A3A1", "A2A4", "A4A2") ~ "Aligned IADL & Mismatched Global Cognition",         Comparison %in% c("A1A2", "A2A1", "A3A4", "A4A3") ~ "Mismatched IADL & Aligned Global Cognition",         Comparison %in% c("A1A4", "A4A1", "A2A3", "A3A2") ~ "Mismatched IADL & Mismatched Global Cognition"       )     ) |>     dplyr::select(Index, Type, Comparison, Independent, Correlated, Difference, Low, High) })

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: Based simulations presented vignette, can conclude correlations FAQ global cognition measures magnitude observed empirical data imply : correlated scenario sensitive PDD, consistently yielding higher PDD rates, correlated scenario produces accuracy estimates similar independent scenario, considering balanced accuracy, correlated scenario diverges independent one nuanced ways, yielding higher estimates comparisons lower others, relative independent scenario, correlated scenario tends slightly overestimate Cohen‚Äôs Œ∫\kappa small degree1, overall, differences correlated independent scenarios likely small magnitude, unless higher correlations diagnostic criteria introduced data-generating process.2

title: Use #1: Targets Pipeline
text: starting, ensure local installation demcrit R package. , see package overview installation instructions, visit package website‚Äôs reference list function documentation. Load package wish access documentation directly RStudio: Next, clone demcrit repository local folder choice (referred studyfolder), install necessary dependencies: Ensure required data files present studyfolder/raw-data directory.
code: library(demcrit) devtools::install_deps()

title: Use #1: Targets Pipeline
text: pipeline first runs data_paths() function, checks missing files naming inconsistencies: Additional functions help prevent data-entry errors structural inconsistencies analysis:
code: help("data_paths") help("check_compatibility") # Looks for incompatibilities between raw item data specific for this project and REDCap data from a larger database. help("check_names") # Looks for inconsistencies in patients names in the raw item data compare to REDCap databes. help("check_ranges") # Looks for impossible test scores.

title: Use #1: Targets Pipeline
text: Finally, make sure apaquarto extension (version 4.4.1) installed studyfolder/_manuscript directory. can run full pipeline (including manuscript writing) via: visualize workflow, use:
code: #install.packages("targets") #install.packages("tarchetypes") targets::tar_make() targets::tar_visnetwork() # full workflow targets::tar_glimpse() # simplified workflow (targets only)

title: Use #2: Out of Pipeline
text: Start loading required packages:
code: library(demcrit) library(gt) # for nicely formatted tables library(tidyverse) |> suppressPackageStartupMessages() # For data wrangling

title: Use #2: Out of Pipeline
text: original dataset shared, simulate similar dataset using built-functions: can inspect default parameters used simulation via: produces following example dataset: Key variables include: id ‚Äì patient identifier type ‚Äì diagnostic algorithm used PDD ‚Äì diagnosis result patient‚Äìalgorithm pair details data generated, see:
code: set.seed(87542) # for reproducibility data <- simulate_pdd_data() prepare_defaults() #> $Mu #>   FAQ  MMSE  MoCA sMoCA  #>  4.05 26.69 24.07 11.26  #>  #> $Sigma #>             FAQ      MMSE      MoCA     sMoCA #> FAQ   23.912100 -2.279718 -4.594644 -3.483636 #> MMSE  -2.279718  4.928400  4.867128  3.284712 #> MoCA  -4.594644  4.867128 12.110400  9.058440 #> sMoCA -3.483636  3.284712  9.058440  7.507600 #>  #> $cens #>       [,1] [,2] #> FAQ      0   30 #> MMSE     0   30 #> MoCA     0   30 #> sMoCA    0   16 #>  #> $crits #>           IADL IADL_thres cognition cognition_thres #> MMSE (1)   FAQ          7      MMSE              26 #> MMSE (2)  FAQ9          1      MMSE              26 #> MoCA (1)   FAQ          7      MoCA              26 #> MoCA (2)  FAQ9          1      MoCA              26 #> sMoCA (1)  FAQ          7     sMoCA              13 #> sMoCA (2) FAQ9          1     sMoCA              13 #> # A tibble: 1,218 √ó 8 #>    id       FAQ  MMSE  MoCA sMoCA  FAQ9 type      PDD #>    <glue> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>     <lgl> #>  1 s1         6    29    25    12     2 MMSE (1)  FALSE #>  2 s1         6    29    25    12     2 MMSE (2)  FALSE #>  3 s1         6    29    25    12     2 MoCA (1)  FALSE #>  4 s1         6    29    25    12     2 MoCA (2)  TRUE #>  5 s1         6    29    25    12     2 sMoCA (1) FALSE #>  6 s1         6    29    25    12     2 sMoCA (2) TRUE #>  7 s2        12    24    21     9     3 MMSE (1)  TRUE #>  8 s2        12    24    21     9     3 MMSE (2)  TRUE #>  9 s2        12    24    21     9     3 MoCA (1)  TRUE #> 10 s2        12    24    21     9     3 MoCA (2)  TRUE #> # ‚Ñπ 1,208 more rows help("simulate_pdd_data") # details on the data generation algorithm help("prepare_defaults") # details on parameter defaults

title: Use #2: Out of Pipeline
text: compute dementia (PDD) rates, first prepare specification diagnostic algorithms variable mappings. , pass summarise_rates() function: Table¬†1: example table showing simulated PDD rates.
code: # Extract default parameters: pars <- prepare_defaults()  # Define algorithm specifications: algos <- with(pars, {data.frame(   type = rownames(crits),   glob = crits$cognition, glob_t = crits$cognition_thres,   iadl = crits$IADL, iadl_t = crits$IADL_thres,   atte = "", atte_t = NA,   exec = "", exec_t = NA,   memo = "", memo_t = NA,   cons = "", cons_t = NA,   lang = "", lang_t = NA )})  # Define variable names: vars <- data.frame(   name = c(unique(algos$glob), unique(algos$iadl)),   label = c(unique(algos$glob), unique(algos$iadl)),   type = "continuous" )  # Compute PDD rates: rates <- summarise_rates(   list(PDD = data, algorithms = algos),   vars = vars,   plot = FALSE # Setting plot to FALSE bacause it is calibrated the data from the study.. )  # Format results: tab1 <- rates$table |>   select(type, Global, IADL, N, Rate) |>   gt_apa_table() |>   cols_label(     type ~ "Algorithm",     Global ~ "Cognitive deficit",     IADL ~ "IADL deficit"   )

title: Use #2: Out of Pipeline
text: Next, can compute pairwise concordance statistics across algorithms: details resulting object, see: can visualize concordance matrices several metrics: () Cohen‚Äôs kappa (b) Raw accuracy (c) Sensitivity (d) Specificity Figure¬†1: Concordance statistic matrices Alternatively, can extract specific concordance statistics present table. Table Table¬†2 shows one example, algorithms sorted raw accuracy predicting MoCA (1). Table¬†2: Example table showing pairwise concordance statistics five algorithms sorted raw accuracy predicting MoCA (1). NIR stands Information Rate, p-values correspond one-sided binomial tests Accuracy > NIR.
code: concs <- describe_concordance(list(PDD = data, algorithms = algos)) help("describe_concordance") help("concords") # describes the concordance statistics table tab2 <- concs$table |>   filter(reference == "MoCA (1)") |>   filter(reference != predictor) |>   arrange(desc(Accuracy_raw)) |>   select(predictor, Kappa, Accuracy, NoInformationRate_raw, AccuracyPValue) |>   mutate(AccuracyPValue = do_summary(AccuracyPValue, 3, "p")) |>   gt_apa_table() |>   fmt_number(decimals = 2) |>   cols_label(     predictor ~ "Predictor",     NoInformationRate_raw ~ "NIR",     AccuracyPValue ~ "p-value"   )

title: Authors and Citation
text: Josef Mana. Author, maintainer. Martina Mana. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Mana J, Mana M (2025). demcrit: Validation Algorithms Parkinson's Disease Dementia. R package version 1.0.1, https://josefmana.github.io/demcrit/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {demcrit: Validation of Algorithms for Parkinson's Disease Dementia},   author = {Josef Mana and Martina Mana},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.1},   url = {https://josefmana.github.io/demcrit/}, }

what: Validation of Algorithms for Parkinson's Disease Dementia
title: Validation of Algorithms for Parkinson's Disease Dementia
text: package intended broad public use. main purpose : provide transparent documentation data analyses forming backbone empirical part Mana et al.¬†(review), supply set functions used generate results, can reused adapted projects similar objectives.

title: Validation of Algorithms for Parkinson's Disease Dementia
text: install local instance package, run:
code: # If you do not have the devtools package, # install it by uncommenting the following line: #install.packages(devtools) devtools::install_github("josefmana/demcrit")

title: Validation of Algorithms for Parkinson's Disease Dementia
text: ensure full reproducibility results, important use package versions originally used generate first place. demcrit package manages package dependencies throug renv. full reproducibility goal, proceeding, please run following code restore package environment exactly used original analysis:
code: # If you do not have the renv package, # install it by uncommenting the following line: #install.packages("renv", version = "1.1.4") renv::restore()

title: Validation of Algorithms for Parkinson's Disease Dementia
text: two main ways work package (described vignette): raw data available ‚Äì Place raw data files data-raw folder run included targets pipeline. See vignette ‚ÄúTargets Pipeline‚Äù details. Without raw data ‚Äì can still use many package functions , similarly structured dataset. See vignette ‚ÄúPipeline‚Äù guidance.

title: Validation of Algorithms for Parkinson's Disease Dementia
text: Currently, demcrit designed around dataset used original study. , primarily supports direct replications rather general applications. find approach useful like adapt data, feel free reach ‚Äî happy discuss possible extensions. also welcome reports bugs mistakes may encounter.

title: Assign Cognitive Impairment Status ‚Äî assign_cognitive_impairment
text: Applies cognitive impairment classification based z-scores computed via normative regression calculator Bezdicek et al. (2017), following Level II PD-MCI criteria proposed Litvan et al. (2012). patient classified cognitively impaired two test scores z < -1.5.

title: Assign Cognitive Impairment Status ‚Äî assign_cognitive_impairment
code: assign_cognitive_impairment(d0, calc, map, output = "both")

what: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
text: comprehensive table containing pairwise comparisons 68 diagnostic algorithms Parkinson‚Äôs Disease Dementia (PDD) evaluated study. table serves basis Figures 2, A3, A4, A5, well summary results presented throughout article.

title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
code: concords

title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
text: tibble 7,744 rows 21 columns: predictor Character; name algorithm used predictor. reference Character; name algorithm used reference. N Integer; number patients used calculations. Kappa Character; Cohen‚Äôs kappa 95% confidence interval. Accuracy Character; accuracy estimate 95% confidence interval. Kappa_raw Numeric; Cohen‚Äôs kappa estimate. McnemarPValue Numeric; p-value McNemar‚Äôs chi-squared test symmetry rows columns. Accuracy_raw Numeric; accuracy estimate. NoInformationRate_raw Numeric; -information rate, .e., accuracy patients classified non-PDD. AccuracyPValue Numeric; p-value Exact Binomial Test comparing accuracy -information rate. Sensitivity Numeric; sensitivity estimate. Specificity Numeric; specificity estimate. Pos Pred Value Numeric; positive predictive value. Neg Pred Value Numeric; negative predictive value. Precision Numeric; precision estimate. Recall Numeric; recall estimate. F1 Numeric; F1 score. Prevalence Numeric; PDD prevalence according reference algorithm. Detection Rate Numeric; detection rate. Detection Prevalence Numeric; detection prevalence. Balanced Accuracy Numeric; balanced accuracy, .e., (sensitivity + specificity) / 2.

title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
text: Generated targets pipeline _targets.R.

title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
text: algorithm used reference predictor, meaning algorithm pair appears twice. metrics, Cohen‚Äôs kappa, symmetrical, whereas others (e.g., accuracy, sensitivity, specificity) .

title: Compute Concordance Measures ‚Äî describe_concordance
text: Computes pairwise concordance statistics different algorithms probable Parkinson‚Äôs disease dementia (PDD). Metrics include Cohen's Kappa, Sensitivity, Positive Predictive Value (PPV), Specificity, Negative Predictive Value (NPV), Accuracy. Visual summaries also generated via ggplot2.

text: d0 list containing PDD diagnostic results, produced diagnose_pdd_sample.

title: Compute Concordance Measures ‚Äî describe_concordance
text: list two components: table data frame summarising pairwise concordance statistics (e.g., Kappa, Accuracy, Sensitivity, Specificity, PPV, NPV). table propagated package data concords plots list ggplot2-based visualisations, including matrices Cohen's Kappa, Accuracy (significance tests Information Rate), Sensitivity, Specificity.

title: Compute Concordance Measures ‚Äî describe_concordance
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data) concmats <- describe_concordance(pdd) } # }

title: Summarise Data ‚Äî do_summary
text: Computes descriptive summaries given vector, optionally including graphical representation (planned future versions). Supports various summary types tailored continuous, binary, nominal variables.

title: Summarise Data ‚Äî do_summary
code: do_summary(x, dec, sum = NULL)

title: Summarise Data ‚Äî do_summary
text: x vector data summarised. dec integer specifying number decimal places numeric summaries. sum character string specifying type summary compute. Possible values: NULL (default) Simple printing vector "N" Number observations "msd" Mean +/- standard deviation "M" Mean "SD" Standard deviation "Md" Median "IQR" Interquartile range "minmax" Minimum-maximum range "Min" Minimum "Max" Maximum "p" p-value (formatted tables) "ptext" p-value (formatted -text reporting) "Nperc" Count percentage binary variables "Nslash" Counts separated slashes nominal variables number categories "estCI" Estimate confidence interval, .e., estimate [CI]

title: Summarise Data ‚Äî do_summary
text: character string numeric summary specified sum.

title: Summarise Data ‚Äî do_summary
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p)  M <- do_summary(data[, 25], 2, "M") SD <- do_summary(data[, 25], 2, "SD") Md <- do_summary(data[, 25], 2, "Md") mm <- do_summary(data[, 25], 0, "minmax") } # }

title: Generate an APA-style Table ‚Äî gt_apa_table

title: Generate an APA-style Table ‚Äî gt_apa_table
text: x tibble data frame formatted APA-style table. grp optional column name (string symbol) use grouping rows via gt::gt()'s groupname_col parameter. Defaults NULL. nms optional column name (string symbol) use row names via gt::gt()'s rowname_col parameter. Defaults NULL. tit character string specifying table title. converted HTML format. Defaults "".

title: Generate an APA-style Table ‚Äî gt_apa_table
text: gt table object formatted according APA style.

what: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
title: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
text: functions prepares dendrogram (tree plot) summarises PDD algorithms construction starting IADL operationalisation top followed successively operationalisation Global cognitive performance, Attention, Executive Function, Construction, Memory Language. dendrogram visualises PDD rate estimated algorithm via point size.

title: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
code: make_dendrogram(tab, top)

title: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
text: tab table containing criteria used generated summarise_rates. top tibble containing top criteria predicting PDD diagnosis Level II generated table_levelII_approximations.

title: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
text: ggplot object dendrogram created ggraph.

title: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Raw data: p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd  <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data)  # PDD rates for point size: vars <- here::here("data-raw", "VariablesOfInterest.csv") rates <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars)  # Concordance with Level II for edge width: algos <- list_algorithms(rates$table) data(concords) best <- table_levelII_approximations(concords, algos, "Accuracy_raw")  tree <- make_dendrogram(rates$table, best$table) } # }

text: list containing: Mu Named numeric vector containing means FAQ, MMSE, MoCA, sMoCA. Sigma Named matrix containing variance-covariance variables (FAQ, MMSE, MoCA, sMoCA). cens matrix named rows denoting scales (FAQ, MMSE, MoCA, sMoCA) two columns - first containing lower bound, second containing upper bound scale. crits data.frame four columns denoting IADL measure use (IADL), threshold IADL measure (IADL_thres), cognitive measure use (cognition), threshold cognitive measure (cognition_thres). Score IADL_thres cognition_thres regarder indicate PDD symptoms. Rownames contain algorithm names.

Language Character; operationalisation language deficit. IADL Character; operationalisation IADL deficit. N Integer; number observations given algorithm. what: Regress PDD via Logistic Regression ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
title: Regress PDD via Logistic Regression ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
text: algorithm probable Parkinson‚Äôs disease dementia (PDD), function fits logistic regression model predicting diagnosis age, sex, interaction. takes input demographic data tibble PDD diagnoses (typically generated via diagnose_pdd_sample).

title: Regress PDD via Logistic Regression ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
code: regress_pdd_on_demographics(d0, d1, covs = NULL, inter = TRUE)

title: Regress PDD via Logistic Regression ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
text: d0 tibble demographic data generated prepare_data. d1 tibble PDD diagnoses (typically PDD element list returned diagnose_pdd_sample). covs Either character vector containing covariates interest (case resulting formula PDD ~ age * sex * (covariate1 + covariate2 + ...), NULL (default case whereby resulting formula PDD ~ age * sex). inter logical indicating whether covariates added together interactions predictors interest (default recommended, TRUE) additive terms (FALSE).

title: Regress PDD via Logistic Regression ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
text: list following components: fits list fitted logistic regression models PDD criterion. values tibble model coefficients statistics. plots named list ggplot2 objects: data Plots showing raw proportions PDD diagnoses age sex. parameters Plots summarising effect sizes (odds ratios) associated p-values.

title: Regress PDD via Logistic Regression ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data0 <- prepare_data(p) data1 <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data0) results <- regress_pdd_on_demographics(data0, data1$PDD) } # }

title: Make Fake Data ‚Äî simulate_pdd_data
text: Prepares minimal example data right format analysis via demcrit package functions. compulsory specify FAQ summary data (mean, variance covariance, see ) least one additional global cognitive measure summary data.

title: Make Fake Data ‚Äî simulate_pdd_data
code: simulate_pdd_data(N = 203, defaults = TRUE, Mu, Sigma, crits, cens = NULL)

title: Make Fake Data ‚Äî simulate_pdd_data
text: N numeric indicating number simulated patients. Defaults 203. defaults logical indicator whether default values derived observed data used (TRUE, default) user provide values instead (FALSE). Mu Named numeric vector means. Needs contain one component denoting FAQ. defaults = TRUE, set values observed data. Sigma Named matrix variances covariances. defaults = TRUE, set empirical values observed data. crits data.frame named rows four columns: rownames indicate algorithm labels, IADL indicate variable data used IADL deficit calculation, IADL_thres indicate threshold IADL deficit, cognition indicate variable data used cognitive deficit calculation, cognition_thres indicate threshold cognitive deficit. cens matrix data frame two columns, first indicating lower bound, second upper bound scale rowname. defaults == TRUE, param = NULL censor data (prints latent scores instead).

title: Make Fake Data ‚Äî simulate_pdd_data
text: tibble containing: id Character; identificator simulated patient. type Character; algorithm names specified rownames crits PDD Logical; PDD diagnosis patient (id) calculated via algorithm (type), raw scores Numeric; Scores showing raw simulated data variable supplied data-generating proces. Defaults columns FAQ, MMSE, MoCA, sMoCA FAQ9.

title: Make Fake Data ‚Äî simulate_pdd_data
text: function simulates N synthetic patients' PDD status via following steps: generate latent FAQ cognitive scores via MASS::mvrnorm(), generate observed FAQ item 9 data via rbinom() following tau-equivalence assumption applied FAQ questionnaire, censor scores according cens round nearest integer obtain observed data apply criteria PDD crits get per algorithm/patient pair probable PDD.

title: Make Fake Data ‚Äî simulate_pdd_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Simulate using defaults: sim1 <- simulate_pdd_data() sim2 <- simulate_pdd_data(defaults = TRUE) # the same data-generating process as sim1  # Generate using two cognitive measures not correlated with FAQ: mu <- c(FAQ = 4.05, MMSE = 26.69, MoCA = 24.07) sd <- c(FAQ = 4.89, MMSE = 2.22, MoCA = 3.48) corrs <- matrix(    c(1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0.63, 0, 0.63, 1), nrow = 3,    dimnames = lapply(seq_len(2), \(i) c("FAQ", "MMSE", "MoCA")) ) cens <- matrix(   c(rep(0, 3), rep(30, 3)), nrow = 3,   dimnames = list(c("FAQ", "MMSE", "MoCA")) ) sigma <- MBESS::cor2cov(corrs, sd) crits <- data.frame(   row.names = c("A1", "A2", "A3", "A4"),   IADL = rep(c("FAQ", "FAQ9"), 2),   IADL_thres = rep(c(7, 1), 2),   cognition = c(rep("MMSE", 2), rep("MoCA", 2)),   cognition_thres = c(rep(26, 2), rep(26, 2)) ) sim3 <- simulate_pdd_data(   N = 2000,   defaults = FALSE, # It is crucial to set this to FALSE   Mu = mu, Sigma = sigma ) } # }

code: specify_algorithms()

title: Specify Algorithms for Probable PDD ‚Äî specify_algorithms

title: Summarise Kappa Coefficients ‚Äî summarise_kappa
text: Using list PDD algorithms stratified IADL deficit operationalisation table pairwise concordance statistics, function extracts raw Cohen‚Äôs kappa estimates computes summary statistics (mean standard deviation) across groups algorithm pairs defined IADL operationalisation scheme.

title: Summarise Kappa Coefficients ‚Äî summarise_kappa
code: summarise_kappa(algorithms, concordance)

title: Summarise Kappa Coefficients ‚Äî summarise_kappa
text: algorithms list containing algorithm mapping generated list_algorithms. concordance tibble containing concordance indexes pairs algorithms generated decribe_concordance. table also available data concords.

title: Summarise Kappa Coefficients ‚Äî summarise_kappa
text: list following components: faq_tot numeric vector containing Cohen's kappas algorithm pairs IADL deficit defined FAQ total > 7. faq_9 numeric vector containing Cohen's kappas algorithm pairs IADL deficit defined FAQ item 9 > 1. cross numeric vector containing Cohen's kappas algorithm pairs different IADL deficit definitions. iadl numeric vector containing Cohen's kappas algorithm pairs differ IADL deficit definition. sums named character vector containing mean standard deviation vector Kappas contained list.

title: Summarise Kappa Coefficients ‚Äî summarise_kappa
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd  <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data) vars <- here::here("data-raw", "VariablesOfInterest.csv")  data(concords) rates <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars) algos <- list_algorithms(rates$table)  # Two equally valid ways to run the function: kappa1 <- summarise_kappa(algos, rates$table) kappa2 <- summarise_kappa(algos, concords) } # }

title: Order and Prints Algorithms ‚Äî summarise_rates
text: function computes summaries estimated PDD rates, stratified diagnostic algorithm.

title: Order and Prints Algorithms ‚Äî summarise_rates
code: summarise_rates(d0, vars, descending = TRUE, plot = TRUE)

title: Order and Prints Algorithms ‚Äî summarise_rates
text: d0 list PDD data generated via diagnose_pdd_sample. vars data.frame, tibble, matrix  following order: variable names, variable labels type variable (continuous, binary, nominal) optional, group, optional, mapping label description table‚Äôs note. Alternatively, path CSV file (semicolon-delimited) containing table. descending logical indicating whether algorithms highest estimated PDD rates listed first (default TRUE). plot logical indicating whether plot PDD rates densities. code dataset-specific (default TRUE).

title: Order and Prints Algorithms ‚Äî summarise_rates
text: list : table tibble containing raw summaries PDD rates. plot ggplot2 object visualising estimated PDD rates. gtable named list gt tables: gtab_rates APA-style gt table summarising results. gtab_algos APA-style gt table listing algorithms used.

title: Order and Prints Algorithms ‚Äî summarise_rates
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd  <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data) vars <- here::here("data-raw", "VariablesOfInterest.csv")  rates0 <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars) rates1 <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars, TRUE)  # rates0 and rates1 are identical rates2 <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars, FALSE) # ascending order } # }

title: Summary Table of Predictors ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
text: helper function prepares table showing five best five worst-performing Level algorithms predicting selected Level II-based diagnosis probable PDD. primarily intended use manuscript keep Quarto document uncluttered.

title: Summary Table of Predictors ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
code: table_levelII_approximations(values, struct, crit)

title: Summary Table of Predictors ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
text: values tibble concordance statistics generated describe_concordance. Can also provided data concords propagated package. struct list generated list_algorithms two elements: [[1]] Character vector Level algorithm names derived using FAQ total > 7 IADL criterion. [[2]] Character vector Level algorithm names derived using FAQ item 9 > 1 IADL criterion. Note: order matters. crit character string indicating concordance statistics used comparisons. Can one "Accuracy_raw", "Balanced Accuracy", "Kappa_raw", "Sensitivity" "Specificity".

title: Summary Table of Predictors ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
text: list containing: table tibble five best five worst Level algorithms predicting specified Level II-based diagnosis probable PDD. gtable gt table object summarising concordance statistics (e.g., accuracy, kappa) five best five worst Level algorithms predicting specified Level II-based diagnosis probable PDD.

title: Summary Table of Predictors ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd  <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data) vars <- here::here("data-raw", "VariablesOfInterest.csv") rates <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars) algos <- list_algorithms(rates$table) data(concords)  # Tables ordered by different statistics: table_levelII_approximations(concords, algos, "Accuracy_raw") # Table 3 table_levelII_approximations(concords, algos, "Balanced Accuracy") # Table 7 table_levelII_approximations(concords, algos, "Kappa_raw") table_levelII_approximations(concords, algos, "Sensitivity") table_levelII_approximations(concords, algos, "Specificity") } # }
